urn:contentItem:5TY5-3NY1-DYN6-W453-00000-00Hints of Democratic agenda as Google CEO testifies2018-12-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:06ZLexisNexisBUSINESS NEWSHints of Democratic agenda as Google CEO testifiesBy MARCY GORDON and BARBARA ORTUTAYAssociated PressWASHINGTON

WASHINGTON (AP) - Google CEO Sundar Pichai - and other tech executives who may be watching - got hints Tuesday of what issues they can expect to face as Democrats take control of the House in three weeks.

While Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee grilled Pichai on what they perceive as bias against conservatives, top committee Democrat Jerrold Nadler said lawmakers should instead examine issues such as the spread of misinformation online and Russians' efforts to influence U.S. elections online.

The issue of user privacy also came up over and over. Looming over the tech industry is the possibility of government regulation intended to protect people's data and a deeper look into whether gigantic companies like Google, Amazon and Facebook need to be broken up.

Pichai's first appearance ever before Congress comes after he angered members of a Senate panel in September by declining their invitation to testify about election manipulation. Pichai's no-show at that hearing was marked by an empty chair for Google alongside the Facebook and Twitter executives who did appear. Lawmakers declined Google's offer to send lower-level executives.

Pichai went to Washington later in September to mend fences, meeting with some two dozen Republicans and indicating he also planned to meet with Democrats. He took part in last week's White House meeting with other tech executives on getting government and businesses working more closely on accelerating emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence.

Pichai reiterated Google's position that it has no plans "right now" to re-enter China with a search engine generating censored results to comply with the demands of that country's Communist government. If that changes, Pichai promised to be "fully transparent" about the move. Pichai has said that he wants Google to be in China serving Chinese users.

The CEO also insisted that Google's search engine is not biased against any political viewpoint.

President Donald Trump has accused Google of rigging search results to suppress conservative viewpoints and highlight coverage from media that he says distribute "fake news." The company has denied any such bias, and while the question has dogged tech companies for years, there's no evidence of an anti-conservative or any other political tilt.

Nadler called the notion of bias a "delusion" and a "right-wing conspiracy theory." The New York Democrat said Tuesday's hearing was the committee's fourth to address the topic - and he suggested he'd move on to other topics as Democrats take control.

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., kicked off the hearing by noting a "widening gap of distrust" between tech companies and the American people.

Asked for yes-or-no answers on what information the company collects, Pichai demurred and attempted to convey that things are more complicated, with varying degrees of success.

Momentum is building in Congress for legislation to put stricter limits and privacy protections around the big tech companies' collection of data.

Rep. Ted Poe, R-Texas, tried to pin down Pichai concretely on privacy. "I've got an iPhone," Poe said, waving his device. "Can Google track me when I move?" If he moved to the left toward his Democratic colleagues on the panel, would Google know?

"Not by default," Pichai answered. Poe demanded a yes or no answer, but Pichai indicated it was complicated.

Trump and some lawmakers have raised the possibility of asking regulators to investigate whether Google -which handles nearly two of every three online searches in the U.S.- has abused its clout as a major gateway to the internet to stifle competition.

Responding to a question about Google's search dominance, Pichai pointed to Amazon's dominance in online shopping.

Pichai, a former engineer, took the helm of Google in 2015 in a major restructuring that made Google a division of conglomerate Alphabet Inc. - whose businesses include Waymo, a self-driving technology development company. Bolstering the dominance of its search engine, Google's Android operating system runs most of the world's smartphones, and its other services - including Gmail, YouTube, online ads and the Chrome web browser - are widely used.

__

Ortutay reported from New York.

While Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee grilled Pichai on what they perceive as bias against conservatives, top committee Democrat Jerrold Nadler said lawmakers should instead examine issues such as the spread of misinformation online and Russians'efforts to influence U.S. elections online.

If that changes, Pichai promised to be "fully transparent" about the move. Pichai has said that he wants Google to be in China serving Chinese users.

The CEO also insisted that Google's search engine is not biased against any political viewpoint. Poe demanded a yes or no answer, but Pichai indicated it was complicated.

Trump and some lawmakers have raised the possibility of asking regulators to investigate whether Google -which handles nearly two of every three online searches in the U.S.- has abused its clout as a major gateway to the internet to stifle competition.

Responding to a question about Google's search dominance, Pichai pointed to Amazon's dominance in online shopping.

Pichai, a former engineer, took the helm of Google in 2015 in a major restructuring that made Google a division of conglomerate Alphabet Inc. - whose businesses include Waymo, a self-driving technology development company. urn:contentItem:5TY5-41J1-JC65-53F0-00000-00Hints of Democratic agenda as Google CEO testifies2018-12-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:06ZLexisNexisBUSINESS NEWSHints of Democratic agenda as Google CEO testifiesBy MARCY GORDON and BARBARA ORTUTAYAssociated PressWASHINGTON

WASHINGTON (AP) - Google CEO Sundar Pichai - and other tech executives who may be watching - got hints Tuesday of what issues they can expect to face as Democrats take control of the House in three weeks.

While Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee grilled Pichai on what they perceive as bias against conservatives, top committee Democrat Jerrold Nadler said lawmakers should instead examine issues such as the spread of misinformation online and Russians' efforts to influence U.S. elections online.

The issue of user privacy also came up over and over. Looming over the tech industry is the possibility of government regulation intended to protect people's data and a deeper look into whether gigantic companies like Google, Amazon and Facebook need to be broken up.

Pichai's first appearance ever before Congress comes after he angered members of a Senate panel in September by declining their invitation to testify about election manipulation. Pichai's no-show at that hearing was marked by an empty chair for Google alongside the Facebook and Twitter executives who did appear. Lawmakers declined Google's offer to send lower-level executives.

Pichai went to Washington later in September to mend fences, meeting with some two dozen Republicans and indicating he also planned to meet with Democrats. He took part in last week's White House meeting with other tech executives on getting government and businesses working more closely on accelerating emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence.

Pichai reiterated Google's position that it has no plans "right now" to re-enter China with a search engine generating censored results to comply with the demands of that country's Communist government. If that changes, Pichai promised to be "fully transparent" about the move. Pichai has said that he wants Google to be in China serving Chinese users.

The CEO also insisted that Google's search engine is not biased against any political viewpoint.

President Donald Trump has accused Google of rigging search results to suppress conservative viewpoints and highlight coverage from media that he says distribute "fake news." The company has denied any such bias, and while the question has dogged tech companies for years, there's no evidence of an anti-conservative or any other political tilt.

Nadler called the notion of bias a "delusion" and a "right-wing conspiracy theory." The New York Democrat said Tuesday's hearing was the committee's fourth to address the topic - and he suggested he'd move on to other topics as Democrats take control.

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., kicked off the hearing by noting a "widening gap of distrust" between tech companies and the American people.

Asked for yes-or-no answers on what information the company collects, Pichai demurred and attempted to convey that things are more complicated, with varying degrees of success.

Momentum is building in Congress for legislation to put stricter limits and privacy protections around the big tech companies' collection of data.

Rep. Ted Poe, R-Texas, tried to pin down Pichai concretely on privacy. "I've got an iPhone," Poe said, waving his device. "Can Google track me when I move?" If he moved to the left toward his Democratic colleagues on the panel, would Google know?

"Not by default," Pichai answered. Poe demanded a yes or no answer, but Pichai indicated it was complicated.

Trump and some lawmakers have raised the possibility of asking regulators to investigate whether Google -which handles nearly two of every three online searches in the U.S.- has abused its clout as a major gateway to the internet to stifle competition.

Responding to a question about Google's search dominance, Pichai pointed to Amazon's dominance in online shopping.

Pichai, a former engineer, took the helm of Google in 2015 in a major restructuring that made Google a division of conglomerate Alphabet Inc. - whose businesses include Waymo, a self-driving technology development company. Bolstering the dominance of its search engine, Google's Android operating system runs most of the world's smartphones, and its other services - including Gmail, YouTube, online ads and the Chrome web browser - are widely used.

__

Ortutay reported from New York.

WASHINGTON (AP) - Google CEO Sundar Pichai - and other tech executives who may be watching - got hints Tuesday of what issues they can expect to face as Democrats take control of the House in three weeks.

While Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee grilled Pichai on what they perceive as bias against conservatives, top committee Democrat Jerrold Nadler said lawmakers should instead examine issues such as the spread of misinformation online and Russians' efforts to influence U.S. elections online.

The issue of user privacy also came up over and over. Looming over the tech industry is the possibility of government regulation intended to protect people's data and a deeper look into whether gigantic companies like Google, Amazon and Facebook need to be broken up.

Pichai's first appearance ever before Congress comes after he angered members of a Senate panel in September by declining their invitation to testify about election manipulation. Pichai's no-show at that hearing was marked by an empty chair for Google alongside the Facebook and Twitter executives who did appear. Lawmakers declined Google's offer to send lower-level executives.

Pichai went to Washington later in September to mend fences, meeting with some two dozen Republicans and indicating he also planned to meet with Democrats. He took part in last week's White House meeting with other tech executives on getting government and businesses working more closely on accelerating emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence.

Pichai reiterated Google's position that it has no plans "right now" to re-enter China with a search engine generating censored results to comply with the demands of that country's Communist government. If that changes, Pichai promised to be "fully transparent" about the move. Pichai has said that he wants Google to be in China serving Chinese users.

The CEO also insisted that Google's search engine is not biased against any political viewpoint.

President Donald Trump has accused Google of rigging search results to suppress conservative viewpoints and highlight coverage from media that he says distribute "fake news." The company has denied any such bias, and while the question has dogged tech companies for years, there's no evidence of an anti-conservative or any other political tilt.

Nadler called the notion of bias a "delusion" and a "right-wing conspiracy theory." The New York Democrat said Tuesday's hearing was the committee's fourth to address the topic - and he suggested he'd move on to other topics as Democrats take control.

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., kicked off the hearing by noting a "widening gap of distrust" between tech companies and the American people.

Asked for yes-or-no answers on what information the company collects, Pichai demurred and attempted to convey that things are more complicated, with varying degrees of success.

Momentum is building in Congress for legislation to put stricter limits and privacy protections around the big tech companies' collection of data.

Rep. Ted Poe, R-Texas, tried to pin down Pichai concretely on privacy. "I've got an iPhone," Poe said, waving his device. "Can Google track me when I move?" If he moved to the left toward his Democratic colleagues on the panel, would Google know?

"Not by default," Pichai answered. Poe demanded a yes or no answer, but Pichai indicated it was complicated.

Trump and some lawmakers have raised the possibility of asking regulators to investigate whether Google -which handles nearly two of every three online searches in the U.S.- has abused its clout as a major gateway to the internet to stifle competition.

Responding to a question about Google's search dominance, Pichai pointed to Amazon's dominance in online shopping.

Pichai, a former engineer, took the helm of Google in 2015 in a major restructuring that made Google a division of conglomerate Alphabet Inc. - whose businesses include Waymo, a self-driving technology development company. Bolstering the dominance of its search engine, Google's Android operating system runs most of the world's smartphones, and its other services - including Gmail, YouTube, online ads and the Chrome web browser - are widely used.

__

Ortutay reported from New York.

WASHINGTON - Google CEO Sundar Pichai - and other tech executives who may be watching - got hints Tuesday of what issues they can expect to face as Democrats take control of the House in three weeks.

While Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee grilled Pichai on what they perceive as bias against conservatives, top committee Democrat Jerrold Nadler said lawmakers should instead examine issues such as the spread of misinformation online and Russians' efforts to influence U.S. elections online.

The issue of user privacy also came up over and over. Looming over the tech industry is the possibility of government regulation intended to protect people's data and a deeper look into whether gigantic companies like Google, Amazon and Facebook need to be broken up.

Pichai's first appearance ever before Congress comes after he angered members of a Senate panel in September by declining their invitation to testify about election manipulation. Pichai's no-show at that hearing was marked by an empty chair for Google alongside the Facebook and Twitter executives who did appear. Lawmakers declined Google's offer to send lower-level executives.

Pichai went to Washington later in September to mend fences, meeting with some two dozen Republicans and indicating he also planned to meet with Democrats. He took part in last week's White House meeting with other tech executives on getting government and businesses working more closely on accelerating emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence.

Pichai reiterated Google's position that it has no plans "right now" to re-enter China with a search engine generating censored results to comply with the demands of that country's Communist government. If that changes, Pichai promised to be "fully transparent" about the move. Pichai has said that he wants Google to be in China serving Chinese users.

The CEO also insisted that Google's search engine is not biased against any political viewpoint.

President Donald Trump has accused Google of rigging search results to suppress conservative viewpoints and highlight coverage from media that he says distribute "fake news." The company has denied any such bias, and while the question has dogged tech companies for years, there's no evidence of an anti-conservative or any other political tilt.

Nadler called the notion of bias a "delusion" and a "right-wing conspiracy theory." The New York Democrat said Tuesday's hearing was the committee's fourth to address the topic - and he suggested he'd move on to other topics as Democrats take control.

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., kicked off the hearing by noting a "widening gap of distrust" between tech companies and the American people.

Asked for yes-or-no answers on what information the company collects, Pichai demurred and attempted to convey that things are more complicated, with varying degrees of success.

Momentum is building in Congress for legislation to put stricter limits and privacy protections around the big tech companies' collection of data.

Rep. Ted Poe, R-Texas, tried to pin down Pichai concretely on privacy. "I've got an iPhone," Poe said, waving his device. "Can Google track me when I move?" If he moved to the left toward his Democratic colleagues on the panel, would Google know?

"Not by default," Pichai answered. Poe demanded a yes or no answer, but Pichai indicated it was complicated.

Trump and some lawmakers have raised the possibility of asking regulators to investigate whether Google -which handles nearly two of every three online searches in the U.S.- has abused its clout as a major gateway to the internet to stifle competition.

Responding to a question about Google's search dominance, Pichai pointed to Amazon's dominance in online shopping.

Pichai, a former engineer, took the helm of Google in 2015 in a major restructuring that made Google a division of conglomerate Alphabet Inc. - whose businesses include Waymo, a self-driving technology development company. Bolstering the dominance of its search engine, Google's Android operating system runs most of the world's smartphones, and its other services - including Gmail, YouTube, online ads and the Chrome web browser - are widely used.

__

Ortutay reported from New York.

urn:contentItem:60KN-1BY1-JCMN-Y512-00000-00'Hipster Antitrust' Movement Takes Center Stage in Congress2020-08-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:06ZLexisNexis'Hipster Antitrust' Movement Takes Center Stage in CongressBradley Arant Boult Cummings LLP

Aug 14, 2020( JD Supra: http://www.jdsupra.com Delivered by Newstex) On Wednesday, July 29, 2020, the House Judiciary Committee's antitrust subcommittee held a widely publicized hearing in which representatives questioned CEOs from Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google about allegedly anticompetitive business practices. This hearing had its genesis in a 2017 Yale Law Journal article[1] by Lina Khan, which gave rise to what became known informally as the 'hipster antitrust' movement.(Not coincidentally, Khan is advising Rep. David Cicilline, the chairman of the Antitrust Subcommittee, and she sat near him during the hearing.)Since the Reagan administration, the development of antitrust law has focused on consumer welfare - typically indicated by low prices - to determine whether competition had been harmed unlawfully.This development was based on then-professor (and later judge) Robert Bork's influential book, The Antitrust Paradox[2], and the libertarian 'Chicago school' of economics.

If prices stay low and customers are happy, then courts are typically reluctant to find any antitrust violation.If the complaining party was a competitor whose business was harmed, it is often met with the response that the antitrust laws exist to protect competition, not individual competitors.More recently, scholars such as Khan have argued that this historical view is too narrow, and they advocate for a broader focus on market structure and the power and influence large tech companies wield.They argue that, rather than merely analyzing whether corporate actions result in lower consumer prices, the law should recognize that the excessive concentration of economic power in a handful of large companies is inherently bad, because it exacerbates other ills, such as income inequality and labor abuses, and gives undue political influence to too few people. Khan's article was specifically about Amazon, a company that famously offers low prices on a wide variety of consumer goods and that has for the most part been well-liked by customers, but which, she argued, exerts a dangerous amount of power to effectively control the online retail economy.The view that companies should not be too big or too powerful is not new; the 'hipster' label is a pejorative term based on the movement's embrace of the views of older scholars, most notably Justice Louis Brandeis, who wrote in the 1930s about the 'curse of bigness.' However, this view is not currently the law. No major antitrust opinions or government enforcement actions this century have been based on the notion that antitrust law prohibits mere 'bigness.'At this point it is impossible to tell whether Congress will actually take any meaningful action to change the law, and the upcoming elections could impact political appetites to make such a change.At various points the 'Big Tech' hearing devolved into political venting and grandstanding, with several representatives routinely interrupting the CEOs' answers to make their own scripted pronouncements. But the hearing was nonetheless a shot across the bow of those firms, signaling that they are being scrutinized more closely than they previously realized.(This may or may not cause those firms to voluntarily alter their practices.) There does appear to be considerable sentiment among both liberals and conservatives that something should be done to check the power of these large companies, and representatives on both sides of the aisle remarked that this was an issue that had unusually high bipartisan support.It is unlikely that companies such as Google or Facebook would be 'broken up' entirely, in part because, despite their faults, they are so popular among their users.But it is possible that certain aspects of their businesses could be spun off or regulated.Congressional action, if any, could take several forms.One possibility is legislation to supplement or amend the existing federal antitrust laws.For example, prior to 2004, some courts recognized 'monopoly leveraging' - i.e., using lawfully obtained monopoly power in one market to confer a competitive leg up to gain market share in another market - as a basis to establish liability under Section 2 of the Sherman Act, which prohibits unlawful monopolization and attempts to monopolize.The U.S. Supreme Court effectively foreclosed that theory in Verizon Communications v. Trinko[3], and although there is respected economic scholarship to support the court's reasoning, not everyone agrees. Congress theoretically could pass legislation to resurrect the monopoly leveraging theory.This may conceivably prevent a large tech company with a monopoly in one market (say online retail sales or social messaging or mobile phones or online search engines) to obtain significant market power in another market (say consumer data). We could also see legislation aimed at political censorship on social media platforms such as Facebook. These are just a couple of examples that Congress could target with specific legislation.Alternatively, proposed legislation could be vague and generalized, such as providing that courts should consider other indicia of economic power and market dominance besides the ability and willingness to raise consumer prices. In other words, Congress could mandate that courts reject the Bork view and adopt the Brandeis/'hipster' view. This would effectively require courts to start over and figure things out on their own, much as they have done historically based on the rather spare language of the Sherman Act and developments in economic scholarship.Rather than new legislation, there could simply be heightened pressure to enforce existing law to punish perceived violations.Certain alleged practices, such as pricing below cost to drive out a competitor or force it to merge, are covered by existing antitrust law, and the Department of Justice already has the tools to bring legal action to prevent those practices.In sum, it remains to be seen whether anything meaningful comes from the hearing.But it did at least demonstrate the bipartisan support for the so-called 'hipster antitrust' concerns that certain tech companies have gotten too big and too powerful, and that existing antitrust law may not be sufficiently equipped to address those concerns. [ 1]: https://www.yalelawjournal.org/note/amazons-antitrust-paradox [ 2]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Antitrust_Paradox [ 3]: https://www.classactiondeclassified.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/26/2020/08/Sup-Materials.Blog_.Declassified.-Verizon-Communications-Inc.-v.-Law-Offices-of-Curtis-V.-Trinko-LLP.-CElder.-Aug-2020.pdf

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60G7-RX01-JDKC-R213-00000-00Historic antitrust hearing in US concludes that big tech must be broken up, regulated2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:06ZLexisNexisHistoric antitrust hearing in US concludes that big tech must be broken up, regulatedNew Delhi

New Delhi, July 30 -- Politicians in the United States (US) grilled chief executives from Amazon, Google, Facebook and Apple in what is sure to be a historic hearing, irrespective of its eventual outcome. The CEOs, Sundar Pichai for Google, Tim Cook from Apple, Jeff Bezos from Amazon and Mark Zuckerberg from Facebook, fielded a wide range of questions from the antitrust bodies.

Representative David N. Cicilline kicked off the hearing saying the panel had conducted a year-long investigation and found that these companies have "wielded their power in disruptive, harmful ways", which risk competition and the country's democracy.

The panel, consisting of representatives from both Republican and Democrat parties, questioned the CEOs on matters ranging from privacy, killing competing startups by either stealing their technology or acquiring them, welding control on the market by abusing the gatekeeper status that some of these platforms hold, and more.

Internal emails haunted Zuckerberg again when he didn't answer a question about whether Facebook copied its competitors. Representative Pramila Jayapal cited an internal email where Zuckerberg himself told Instagram's co-founder Kevin Systrom that Facebook would build a copycat camera app, during the negotiations with Instagram. Emails were also unearthed where Zuckerberg was found to have aspired to buy Google.

Amazon was accused of similar behaviour, along with using data about third party sellers from its platform to kill small businesses. In addition, Representative Hank Johnson cited the widespread availability of counterfeit products on Amazon's e-commerce platform, asking Bezos why the company isn't responsible for it.

Bezos, in turn, said that Congress itself should address this issue, adding that the company itself also takes measures to avoid counterfeit products. "I would encourage this body to pass stricter penalties for counterfeiters and to increase law enforcement resources to go after counterfeiters," he said.

Further, facing questioning from representative Jamie Raskin, Bezos acknowledged that Amazon does use its platform to promote its own products over rivals that don't have the same features.

"I'm sure there are cases where we do promote our own products," said Bezos, adding that it's a common practice in business. "And so it wouldn't surprise me if Alexa sometimes does promote our own products," he said, answering a question about its voice assistant recommending Amazon Basics batteries over others.

Bezos also said that Amazon has policies to prevent the users of seller data to kill sellers, but couldn't confirm that the policies have never been violated. Representative Lucy McBath even played a recording of a bookseller on Amazon, who claimed that Amazon's practices had all but killed her business.

On the other hand, Apple's Tim Cook was questioned on the 30% commission it charges developers on the App Store for payments. Cook argued that the entry doors to the App Store are wide open and that the 30% commission is much lesser than what developers would pay before the App Store came into being.

Asked whether he would increase commissions ever, Cook pointed out that the company had never increased commissions since the App Store's launch. He also claimed that competition would keep Apple from doing so in future too.

For Google, most questions were targeted around its overall dominance over the Internet. The politicians asked Pichai questions about Google's dominance on news and cited data suggesting it has been unfair to news publishers, how it uses user data, and whether it steals data from competing companies and websites.

Pichai also admitted, during the hearing, that while Google Search is automated, there is a manual component to how the company blacklists a website.

Additionally, the four CEOs were asked whether they believed that the Chinese government steals tech from US companies. To this, both Pichai and Cook said their companies' data has never been stolen, to their first hand knowledge. However, Zuckerberg said it's "well documented" that China steals tech from the US, while Bezos said he has heard reports of it, but hasn't personally seen it. Pichai later added that in 2009 the company had suffered a cyber attack from the country.

In perhaps the easiest question in the hearing, all four CEOs pledged not to work with companies that use slave labour.

The four hour long hearing grilled all four companies, and showed that lawmakers were much more ready this time than in earlier hearings with such companies. While the outcome of this hearing will take time to materialise, the questions show a willingness by lawmakers to regulate these platforms. Several representatives on the panel also asked the companies why they shouldn't be broken up, because they're too big.

"Today we had the opportunity to hear from four of the most powerful companies in the world. This hearing has made one fact clear to me, these companies as they exist today have monopoly power. Some need to be broken up, all need to be properly regulated and held accountable. We need to ensure that the antitrust laws first written more than a century ago work in the digital age. When these laws were written the monopolists were men named Rockefeller and Carnegie. Their controls of the marketplace allows them to do whatever it took to crush independent businesses and expand their own power. The names have changed, the stories are the same. Today the names are Zuckerberg, Cook, Pichai and Bezos. Once again their control of the marketplace allows them to do whatever it takes to crush independent business and expand their own power. This must end," concluded Chairman Cicilline.

The subcommittee will next publish a report on its findings and suggest solutions to the problems before it, at a later date.

Doug Collins (R) Georgia; Small Business Struggling; Amazon Puts New Grocery Delivery Customers On Wait List; Michael Avenatti Temporarily Released From Jail Amid Virus Fear; Historical Deal 23 Countries Agree To 9.7 Million Barrel Per Day Cut; Apple And Google Team Up To Help Curb COVID-19 Spread2020-04-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:06ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTMitch Roschelle, Lee Carter, Kurt Knutsson, Rep. Doug Collins, Meghan OgilvieNEWSFinancial041302cb.231Historic Oil Cuts; Reopening the U.S. Economy; Battle over Additional Coronavirus Relief; Deadly Storms; On the Mend; Chinese Government Imposes New Regulations that Delay PPE Exports to the U.S.; Interview with Rep. Doug Collins (R) Georgia; Small Business Struggling; Amazon Puts New Grocery Delivery Customers On Wait List; Michael Avenatti Temporarily Released From Jail Amid Virus Fear; Historical Deal 23 Countries Agree To 9.7 Million Barrel Per Day Cut; Apple And Google Team Up To Help Curb COVID-19 SpreadMaria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone, Dagen McDowell, Judge Andrew Napolitano, Janice Dean

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Monday, April 13th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast on the button.

And historic oil deal has been reached. The United States stepping in to broker a deal resulting in 23 countries, including Saudi Arabia and Russia, agreeing to cut production. A record cut of nearly 10 million-barrels a day, about a tenth of the world's oil supply. Prices of oil this morning are fractionally higher, up 1.5 percent. There is speculation this cut could go even more than 10 percent. We're watching this.

The U.S. now leads the world in coronavirus deaths and confirmed cases but there are still signs the curve is leveling out. And, of course, we do not know the accuracy of China's numbers.

President Trump saying America is winning the war against the virus. Meanwhile Dr. Anthony Fauci says at least part of the U.S. economy could reopen next month.

Checks are now getting deposited into Americans' accounts but over at the Capitol, the battle over additional funding for small business rages this morning. Congressional Republican looking to add $251 billion. Democrats looking for more money and a much broader use of that money.

Meanwhile sources are telling me that the Chinese government is instituting new rules interfering in the production and much-needed export of personal protective equipment to the United States. The Chinese Communist Party has instituted new regulations putting a delay on any exports of this personal protective gear export out to the world.

Markets this morning are lower. Futures indicating a decline at the start of trading. We are kicking off a big week ahead of quarterly earnings. We will get JP Morgan, a number of others, Johnson and Johnson later on in the week.

Going into the earnings period, we've got the Dow Jones Industrial average futures down 243 points. The S&P futures lower by 27. And the Nasdaq futures lower by 75.

This after the U.S. markets rallied last week. The Dow, the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 all up better than 10 percent. It was one of the best weeks since 1974 for the S&P 500. S&P had the best week since '74 last week with a gain of 12 percent on the session -- of the entire week rather.

Deadly storms slamming parts of the United States Easter weekend. The southeast still being battered this morning by weather. We will have a live update on what to expect.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA is live right now.

And global markets are lower this morning. In Asia overnight it was red across the board as you can see. Worst performer was Japan, down two and a third percent. Hong Kong was closed for a holiday.

And European markets are also closed this morning for Easter Monday. The Easter holiday continues and as you can see the Asian markets were largely lower.

Yields meanwhile are fractionally up. Yields on the 10-year treasury right now looks like this and it is sitting -- it is sitting at 0.723 percent. That is down 0.6 basis points this morning on treasury yields. Had been up but has reversed course.

Joining the conversation this morning: Dagen McDowell, Lee Carter and Mitch Roschelle are here. Great to see everybody this morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Great to see you -- Maria.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY & PARTNERS: Good to see you.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNER: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: I hope you had a great Easter.

Now, some of our top stories we are watching this morning and once again a deadly round of more than 30 tornadoes ripping across several southern states this morning. More than half a million people do not have power this morning.

Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi -- all declaring states of emergency today. The storms killing at least eight people including a Mississippi deputy and his wife. In Alabama a woman is rescued after getting trapped in her car. And hundreds of homes are destroyed in Louisiana. Georgia now getting hit with the dangerous track moving north. Severe thunderstorms and strong winds expected to move across the northeast today.

President Trump delivering a message of hope meanwhile yesterday in his Easter address. He told Americans we are winning the battle against the coronavirus. This as the FDA says that the virus is nearing a peak in the United States.

Over the weekend, the President approved the disaster declaration for Wyoming. This means all 50 states now and territories have received a federal disaster declaration. More than 22,000 people have died in the United States.

But there is hope as New York sees a slight flattening in new viruses -- new cases of the virus. Experts are hoping that this trend becomes more widespread leading toward the country slowly reopening beginning next month.

And some more good news this morning. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is out of the hospital. After receiving treatment for the coronavirus, Johnson home after a weeklong hospital stay including spending three days in the ICU. The Prime Minister thanked doctors for saving his life.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BORIS JOHNSON, BRITISH PRIME MINISTER: I've seen the personal courage, not just of the doctors, the nurses, but of everyone. It is thanks to that courage, that devotion, that duty and that love that our NHS has been unbeatable.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We're happy he is feeling better. It is not clear when Johnson will return to work. We will keep covering that, of course.

Meanwhile breaking news this morning, sources telling me that China is imposing new rules and regulations on a local level on all materials used to make personal protective equipment. You need the approval in order to export any of this.

The new regulations have resulted in major delays in sending the gear to the United States and across the world.

Gordon Chang, author of "The Coming Collapse of China", with me earlier reacting to the breaking news in the last hour.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GORDON CHANGE, AUTHOR, "THE COMING COLLAPSE OF CHINA": You know, Beijing has this constant anti-American propaganda which just even in the best of times exists. And so this is having consequences and it's certainly hurting sales to the United States of this equipment.

BARTIROMO: Chang is also telling me that Beijing is using its new approval powers to actually divert supplies away from America to countries that it considers friendlier.

Joe Biden meanwhile accused of sexually assaulting a former aide. Tara Reed was just a Senate staffer for Biden nearly 30 years ago. She is alleging that the assault happened in the basement of a Capitol Hill office building back in 1993. Reed has filed a criminal complaint in Washington. She did this last week. The presumptive Democratic presidential nominee meanwhile is denying all of these charges.

A stunning scene over in Rio de Janeiro. The iconic Christ the Redeemer statue lit up to look like a doctor in Brazil. The display honoring healthcare workers fighting the virus across the world. And a priest is sending blessings from above flying in a helicopter asking for prayers to watch over the city.

Getting more money to the American people is the priority in Washington now. Lawmakers from both sides of the aisle are devising with new plans to make sure that our workers' paychecks are covered during COVID-19 pandemic. The plans however differing on the level of government and aid involved.

Joining me right now is Georgia Congressman Doug Collins. And Congressman - - it's always great to see you. Thank you so much for joining us.

REP. DOUG COLLINS (R), GEORGIA: Good morning -- Maria. Good to see you as well.

BARTIROMO: I know you have been able to secure hydroxychloroquine for the state of Georgia. I want to get to that in a moment.

But first let's talk about the paycheck program because I've been hearing from a lot of small business, Congressman -- and you know that there has -- it's been a messy start, if you will. And there are some small businesses that are asking, pleading to change the timeline where they can't take the money now to give it out over an eight-week period and then have to only be timed to that eight-week period because that's not going to stop them from going bankrupt because they don't have any demand. They are shut down.

COLLINS: You're right -- Maria. Maria -- you're right. And what we've got to look at -- President Trump made it very clear and Vice President Pence and the Congress made it very clear that the thing we needed to do was take care of the two parts, the health of our nation and the economy of our nation.

And by doing so, by putting the priority on making sure that our first responders, doctors and everyone got the help that they needed. Then also putting money in people's paychecks, making sure businesses can keep employees as long as they possibly can.

And those are the two priorities. And what -- what we're trying to do now is to get more money into that. But what you just talked about is very true. We took a program that was nonexistent a little less than two and a half, 3 weeks ago and started that program.

And there have been things that we have now found. I mean there's nothing a program this large, you will not find areas in which we need to make flexibility. And what I've been impressed with is the President and his team have tried to make it easy. As we have seen them come up, tried to make these arrangements the Small Business Administration with our banks so that they can have the flexibility so businesses can stay in business. So that when we do something for the health part, the economy is going to be able to start back sooner rather than later.

BARTIROMO: So how do you think we should reopen the economy -- Congressman? How should the country be balancing the scientific community's recommendations and the economic realities when it comes to reopening the economy? Do you have a plan?

And what about testing that we will know who has been testing? Who's been inoculated when we get to that point obviously. We don't have a vaccine yet in terms of making sure they know they're good to go back to work.

COLLINS: Well, several things there. One -- and it's amazing you made a comment earlier about it's been amazing how the American people have pulled together. I've been contacted by (INAUDIBLE) even here in Georgia and sort of an at-home plasma separator where you can get those antibodies and you could see those quicker.

Dr. Brix had talked about that, others they've talked about that as well. And they've been contacted and they're stepping forward, they're making the technology known. Others are doing that as well.

I think what we've got to see is what the President said is we're going to continue this process, I think through April. But we're seeing and as you said earlier, some flattening is occurring. The social distancing is working, making people aware of this and not getting too quick, so that you'll be able to get toward the end of this month, be able to take the moneys that have been put in for stimulus and then have our businesses start opening in certain areas.

I think you'll see some areas open up quicker than others. It just depends on where the virus is staging at. But I think you have to take both the science and the economics in display here as we continue this. We can't stay shutdown forever and I think we've gotten -- but we've also got make it sure that we're also taking care of people's health as well.

BARTIROMO: Is it realistic to think that we can start opening some parts of the economy next month?

COLLINS: I think it's a possibility. I think you're going to have to continue to look at how the virus is developing and the hot spots that are developing and are we still seeing growth in certain areas and how we can do it.

The economy in many areas is struggling because especially (INAUDIBLE) and Georgia is a prime example of it with tourism and service industries and those that are being killed.

I spoke to a hotelier the other day who normally has 90 percent -- 95 percent. He's in the business area. He's at 6 percent and 7 percent occupancy. These are the kind of things that's going to take time to get back up.

But also in light of these things we're also going to find new areas of growth in our economy that we didn't have before in the -- in our telecommuting and how we are talking, how we're communicating.

These are going to offer up new opportunities as well even as businesses get back into play. We may see a whole different economy verge out of this.

BARTIROMO: So Congressman -- what are you working on now in terms of this next stimulus package? Will there be a fourth relief package? Are you expecting that? And what should go in it?

COLLINS: There's probably going to be at least one more. What we are dealing with right now is very frustrating -- Maria. We need to make sure, as you talked about and we just talked about (INAUDIBLE). Small businesses in the payroll protection plan, we need to make sure these payrolls are protected, these businesses can have the money that they need keep to going and not just go out of business at this time. And we need to put the $251 billion that the President has asked for in this package right now so that some time this week we are not actually just getting to pay for it straight but have no money. We need to make sure it continues the process.

The Democrats however want to continue a negotiated process which we are adding money for other things that moneys are still available for. What we need to do is take this first step now.

They'll be more negotiations. Mitch McConnell, Kevin McCarthy, the President have always said there's other things that we're going to have to keep working on. But we need to get this money in here now. Otherwise businesses won't have the assurances after they get through the process that there'll be money available. We need to get that done now.

BARTIROMO: Well -- there's so many important things that you need to address, in particular this supply chains issue. I know Peter Navarro at the White House is working on this in terms of getting companies to come back, bring their supply chains here.

This has been going on for three administrations and I guess, you know, with all due respect, and Nancy Pelosi and her colleagues have been looking for ghosts in the Russia collusion narrative for three years and while doing so they have completely missed the real bad actor here and that's China who's been eating our lunch for decades.

COLLINS: Well, think about what you just said there --

BARTIROMO: What are you going to do about it?

COLLINS: Well, I think you just brought up a great point. Think about the distractions of the last year before we ever got here. When the President was talking about trade deals after we had went through our time of getting our the tax plan done, getting our economy going as much as it was and then the President transitioning into tacks (ph) where we held the -- even we held the Mexican-Canadian trade agreement up for almost a year because of these investigations --

BARTIROMO: That's right.

COLLINS: -- and everything else. We held all that up. At the same point, we are missing the supply chain where the President was talking about this in his deals with China. He's talking about bringing those companies back and making sure our supply chain was secure.

Now we are seeing it. When you wake up one morning and you have a pandemic and you see that a vast majority of our pharmaceutical supply chain was based in China, when you see, as you talked about earlier, this PPE issue now of getting -- where China is clamping down on it, where you see that it makes it even more -- Peter is right about this. Navarro couldn't be more right.

We have to make sure that the incentive from the tax plan early or incentives earlier to bring the supply chains back. It's got to be one of the first and foremost things we do. It also will help us in our economic condition as we come out of this because you're growing jobs and growing manufacturing here in the United States.

But when it comes to our military supplies, when it and comes to our pharmaceutical supplies, when it comes to the various things that we are now seeing that are in danger, we have to put a priority on that.

The President has been talking this ever since he was sworn in. It's now time for Congress to put aside these kind of partisan squabbles and say look here is the real bad actors on the world stage. We have to take an aggressive stance towards them.

BARTIROMO: But will a supply chain element be in a fourth relief package -- Congressman?

COLLINS: I would like that. I think, you know, we need something addressed. I think we need to also make sure that we're making sure that American companies are not exporting things overseas that can be used here first.

BARTIROMO: Right.

COLLINS: We've had some reports of that. I've made that issue very clear with the White House and others as we sign on to things. This stuff needs to stay here first because that's our first priority.

BARTIROMO: Yes, of course. Congressman -- it's good to see you, this morning. Thanks so much.

COLLINS: Great to be with you -- Maria. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Have a good Monday.

Doug Collins. Doug Collins joining us. We will be right back. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Severe weather slamming parts of the United States, Fox News senior meteorologist Janice Dean with the details on the extent of this damage and what Americans can expect today. It's coming. Hey -- Janice.

JANICE DEAN, FOX NEWS SENIOR METEOROLOGIST: Yes. Here in the northeast -- Maria, we're going to have wind gusts in excess of 60 miles per hour, possibly hurricane-force winds. But the damage across Texas through Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia, up towards the Carolinas is extensive. In some cases catastrophic. We had one tornado on the ground for 100 miles yesterday in Mississippi and these storms are packing a punch throughout the morning and the afternoon.

They will weaken but we are going to see that straight line wind damage potential especially over portions of the southeast up towards the mid- Atlantic and even the northeast where we have wind advisories for tens of millions of Americans here. D.C. up towards Philadelphia, New York back through the Great Lakes where again, it's going to be incredible as we go through the morning hours with the potentials for not only power outages but structural damage. So this is going to be a big deal.

There are your forecast winds coming this morning into this afternoon. And in some cases, yes, hurricane-force winds along the coast and that's going to be very problematic unfortunately. If we have power outages and people are in their homes, it's going to be trying to say the least.

There's your forecast throughout the day today. The storms will move offshore but in the meanwhile the damage is done with the incredible videos coming out of the south and the southeast. Our hearts and prayers -- Maria, out to all of those folks. This was a severe weather outbreak, a tornado catastrophe in some of these regions.

Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Janice -- thank you. Janice Dean with the latest on weather.

Meanwhile we've got breaking news. Goldman Sachs is saying that U.S. stocks have likely bottomed on policy support. They will not go lower because of the "do whatever it takes policy" approach by lawmakers.

And Dagen -- you're talking about now fiscal stimulus between the central bank and the government. $7.5 trillion dollars in fiscal stimulus. That's 35 percent of the GDP -- Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Right and some of that is yet to come from the Federal Reserve. At least a couple of trillion dollars more potentially. That's what Goldman Sachs, David Kostin strategist, including him say about the U.S. stock market and the economy.

This unprecedented combination of fiscal and monetary policy support and then also the flattening of the viral curve. They don't think -- if the U.S. doesn't have a second surge in infections after the economy reopens, equity markets are unlikely to make new lows, but what is the low we are talking about?

These policy actions, their previous near-term downside was 2000 on the S&P 500. However, we're -- right now as of Thursday's close, we are 25 percent above the recent low. The recent low was on March 23rd of 2237. So we are still significantly higher than the recent low but what Goldman Sachs is saying is it's wiping away that 2000 call and so it's sticking with it won't make a new low below that 2237. We've had a really big bounce-back since that March 23rd low which is worth noting.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's at least 23 percent or so from the lows just recently, so we will probably still see the 700 or 800-point moves up and down but we have seen the lows.

I like that. I'll take it.

Let's take a break. We've got a lot more to come this morning.

We are looking at a decline of about 300 point son the Dow Industrials.

Stay with us. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Small business in America struggling amid coronavirus shutdowns. Many businesses uncertain about the future. The government stepping in, of course, to help offering the Paycheck Protection Program which guaranties loans to small businesses with the goal of helping them keep their employees on the job during the pandemic. The goal is to get that money and give it to employees who are at home.

My next guest is small business owner who applied for that program and it has asked for a loan.

Joining me right now is Dog Tag Bakery CEO, Meghan Ogilvie. And Meghan -- thanks very much for joining us. Tell us about your story. You applied for the loan, and you got -- did you get the money?

MEGHAN OGILVIE, CEO, DOG TAG BAKER: You know, we are still, like many small business owners and nonprofits, we are still waiting to hear back on that as of now.

You know, as a small business and we are nonprofit based in Washington, D.C. that serves veterans, service connected to disabilities, no (INAUDIBLE) and no charge care givers, we have a mission behind our bakeries. It's a living business school to teach entrepreneurship and small business but also really rediscover purpose and community.

So we are doing everything we can in the sense that we have applied for the SBA disaster loan. We've submitted all of the documentation that we know of as of right now for the Paycheck Protection Plan. And we are doing our best obviously forecast to project the financial viability of our organization just like many others out there with the difficult part of not knowing the end date.

And so we are right now really navigating it the best we can and still maintaining our program and running our fellowship, providing tools for our alumni to understand how to navigate it as they are small business owners or employees who've lost their jobs during this time.

BARTIROMO: So you applied for the Small Business Administration disaster loan, $300,000. The Paycheck Protection Plan, $275,000. D.C. micro grant and then -- I want to ask you, I mean your business has gone through a series of stages, right, from reducing store hours, ceasing producing, now to closing your brick and mortar altogether and online store.

So what are the projected financial impacts from the coronavirus virus shutdown from your standpoint? And once you get this loan and you give that money, much of the money to your employees who are home, but you're still under shutdown, is that going to -- is that going to be enough for you or are you going to need to use other levers?

OGILVIE: You know, Maria, it's a great question. As of March 12th, we started limiting hours. From there we went to curb-side and pickup only. From there we went to shipping only. And by the 30th we had to shut down our full operation based on costs and based also on the safety and health and wellness of our team as well as our community.

And what we are seeing is right now we are just trying to fill the hole that is right now so we are at a minimum of $130,000 at least lost. And that's just by the normal orders that we have coming in through catering or retail or wholesale. So that's just at a minimum. That's what we know we've lost, what our projections are showing from last year.

And that does incur (ph) any other new business that would be coming in. So we know right now we are at a deficit already and that does not include the payroll that we are continuing to pay our entire team because our team is everything. And small business and nonprofit, you know, your team is what makes the special sauce to the organization and keeps it running.

So what we are seeing with this loan and from the SBA disaster loan, as well as the Paycheck Protection Plan, that's really just for the stop gap right now, that's to help stop the bleed. But you know, we are all hoping and wanting to get through this very difficult time, an unprecedented time but, you know, what's going to happen when we get back and the mandates start getting lifted and restrictions get eased?

You know, we don't know as a community how our community's going to react. You know, we are a bakery that is a living business school for veterans, that you know, you come in and have a cup of coffee and support a nonprofit.

But the concern is right now we don't know how the community is going to participate moving forward. The social distancing and everything that's going on right now -- so what we are also trying to obviously forecast for is, you know, what is going to happen when we go back into operation and the reaction of, you know, will business go back to usual or how -- what the implications will be.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, we are talking about testing and that's going to be one lever to get us back into the opening and reopening of the economy. We want to take a look at that coming up.

Meghan -- it's great to get your insights this morning. Thanks very much.

OGILVIE: Thank you so much for having us.

BARTIROMO: Meghan Ogilvie joining us this morning.

Coming up, coronavirus and bail reform. We will take a look how it's ripping through the prison system as well.

Back in a moment.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Monday, April 13th. Hope you're having a good morning, your top stories right now 7:32 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets are pointing to a lower opening this morning. We're kicking off a new week where we will get first quarter earnings beginning at the end of the week. Dow Futures down 140 points right now, the NASDAQ Futures lower by 35, and the S&P Futures down 16 points.

There is an historic oil deal to report, the USA stepping in to broker a deal resulting in 23 countries including Saudi Arabia and Russia, agreeing to a record cut in production of nearly 10 million barrels cut a day, about a 10th of the world supply. The deal failing to excite investors, oil prices this morning are flat. A lot of investors out there writing in their morning notes today that they wanted more. The price of oil is up $0.16 a barrel, that's tree-quarter of one percent at 22.94.

Global Markets this morning look like this. In Asia, it was red across the board. Take a look and you will see Hong Kong closed for a holiday but the others down across the board. The Nikkei average in Japan, the worst performer, down 2-1/3 percent.

European markets are also closed this morning for Easter Monday, a holiday.

Meanwhile this, the FBI is investigating a COVID-19 scam. Cheryl Casone with the details there and yes, there are lots of scams lately. This is the latest that the bad guys are turning to COVID-19, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, Maria. And more and more are probably going to keep coming out. California's healthcare union says that it was conned over much needed supplies. The union thought it struck a deal to buy 39 million N95 masks but they never got them. FBI says that individuals in Australia and Kuwait had contacted the would be recipients through WhatsApp. Fortunately, no money was ever exchanged. But Yes, at this point, this is where we're at.

Well, a surge in food deliveries is forcing Amazon to put new online grocery customers on a waitlist that starts today. The company also is looking to shorten shopping hours at some Whole Foods stores that workers can fill online requests for Amazon Fresh and Amazon Prime now. Company also plans to hire more workers to meet the growing demand for food deliveries during the coronavirus pandemic. There's Amazon in the premarket, just down a fraction as you can see.

And Maria, how does Tampa Brady sound or maybe Tampa Bay. Tom Brady is hoping his new home is going to help him make a little extra cash. The six times Super Bowl champion wants to sell merchandise using those two phrases. Brady's company TEB Capital Management filed trademark applications last week for those phrases. Brady, Maria, signed a two-year deal with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers last month after 20 seasons with the New England Patriots. I know, shocker. Tom Brady's going to cash in on this new deal. You know, who knew? Back to you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: It's true. It was a really shocker to everybody though, so we'll keep watching that. Cheryl, thank you.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: We are taking a look at more implications of the coronavirus and how it is impacting bail reform and the prison system. Lawyer Michael Avenatti temporarily released from a New York City jail over concerns of coronavirus. Avenatti has to report back in 90 days. This as New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio has called for releasing hundreds of prisoners who are at risk of coronavirus.

On "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES", I spoke with both New York Governor Andrew Cuomo and former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani about the bail reform issue, here's a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Will you propose or support that judges have the discretion to let out criminals as they see fit?

GOV. ANDREW CUOMO (D-NY): Bail reform for many years was based on how much money you had, Maria. That's what cash bail is. If you're rich, you get out. If you're poor, you sit. That's an injustice, not justice.

I understand the fear. I understand the criticism. I said that I'm working on it and I believe we're going to get something done.

RUDY GIULIANI, FORMER MAYOR OF NEW YORK CITY: The prisons are overwhelmed with COVID-19. We tell people stay home because there may be COVID-19 in your home and you don't want to bring it outside and we're letting the prisoners out so they can bring that COVID-19 that's ramping into prison. They could bring it to us. Are you crazy?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Well, joining me right now is Fox News Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. Judge, great to see you this morning. You know, I've got a very important source in law enforcement who told me that she is looking every day at requests, thousands of requests from families who want their family members out of prison, because of COVID-19. She's got to review all of these -- all of these applications because de Blasio wants them out. What do you think?

JUDGE ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: Well, this is a difficult problem for the government. It's a problem of resources. I mean, do they want to keep COVID-19 prisoners in jail and care for them and treat them in jail. And what is basically an unsafe unsanitary, hardly medical environment, or do they want to send them out on their own where they are free to infect other people or go to someplace? Many of them have no places to go.

So, Mayor Giuliani's comments are very well taken. You know, I'm a fan of Governor Cuomo. I think he's using his bully pulpit brilliantly, but he signed the bail reform law which takes discretion away from judges, and requires that people -- even people that are repeat offenders be set free as long as they don't reach a certain level of violence.

So somebody spits on you or slaps you in the face, as long as they don't break a bone or break the skin, they don't get bail, they immediately are released. So he's part of the problem for this.

The solution to the bail issue is the way the Feds do it, which is to give judges discretion to evaluate each person. What is the likelihood that this person will repeat the crime? What is the likelihood that this person will go home? What is the likelihood that this person will infect somebody else with COVID-19? You can't do it by a formula or a computer, you have to have a judge with a prosecutor and a defense lawyer resolving this together.

BARTIROMO: Yes, well, look, in that interview with Governor Cuomo, he said to me that he's going to make a decision on this on whether to change or tweak this bail reform law by April 1st. So here we are on April 13th, we haven't heard anything. Obviously, he's been a little busy and he's been showing great leadership on the COVID-19 situation.

NAPOLITANO: Right.

BARTIROMO: But we will get -- we will get a resolution here at some point. He's got to look at this again. He's under pressure to do so.

And Dagen, as we watch all of this happened, the crime numbers in New York are going up, up and up because of all of those inmates and other reasons that had been let out and now we're just going to see more inmates coming out because of this latest problem of COVID-19.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, it's only getting worse. New York has turned into an extremely scary place. It feels like Grand Theft Auto at times. There are -- I think it was Melissa Francis posted a video on Twitter yesterday of a gang of people on dirt -- motorized dirt bikes and motorcycles. A giant group of people riding not just up the street, but on the sidewalks.

I walk around my neighborhood and it's one car after another has had its window busted out. It might be vandalism, it might be theft. But there is - - there is mass at a -- at a very minimum civil disobedience going on, but criminal activity on every street in this city. And it's rampant, and it probably won't go away because of this bail reform.

BARTIROMO: In New York in general, it's up in the double digits, Lee Carter. And this is an issue that the governor and the mayor will have to deal with as they try to figure out how to isolate inmates who have COVID- 19.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: I mean, it's a really, really complicated issue. Obviously, as the judge was saying that there's no -- there's no way to really manage the health of all of these inmates in the prisons. You're putting all these other people at risk.

But is there a precedent here Judge, for why they would do it this way, handle it this way, let these people out. I mean, it doesn't seem to make sense to say go away for 90 days and then come back. This has happened elsewhere?

NAPOLITANO: There's no precedent Lee, of which I'm aware for letting people like, for example, Michael Avenatti out. Now, Avenatti is no longer presumed innocent because he's already been convicted. Technically, the conviction isn't finalized until sentencing. And in his case, sentencing is June 17th.

But a jury found him guilty of attempting to extort Nike for $25 million. We all remember the case because they taped him of trying to shake them down.

I was quite surprised that he was let a free, however, he's not a flight risk. Everybody knows what he looks like. He has a home to go to. He has the means with which to address any health issues that he may have. So he's an unusual but an easy case.

It is the poor person who's committed a violent crime who's sick with COVID-19 whom prison officials don't want to physically touch. That is the problematic and troublesome case that Mayor Giuliani was discussing with Maria yesterday.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but this goes back to the -- to the same old issue that people have such problems with, it's the -- it's the successful rich guy who gets out. And the poor guy or gal who's in there, who -- I'm not -- I'm not talking about serious -- you know, I'm not talking about murder. But I'm talking about someone who had -- who is in there for a lot less of a reason and yet he's still in there and Avenatti gets out, why? Well, how come he got out?

NAPOLITANO: Well, Avenatti got out because a judge decided, not the judge who presided over his trial in white plains, but the judge was about to preside over his trial in Los Angeles that he's not a flight risk, and he's not a danger to society.

BARTIROMO: OK.

NAPOLITANO: And he will show up when needed. That really does not have to do with his wealth, that has to do with the fact that he's so well-known he couldn't harm a fly without somebody seeing him and reporting it.

BARTIROMO: Alright, we will be watching that. Judge, great to get your insights as always, stay safe, stay strong. Judge Andrew Napolitano, we will see you soon.

Quick break and then we will be right back looking at markets on a Monday. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, we are starting the week off with a pretty good selloff. Futures indicating a decline at the start of trading. Take a look at markets right here with the Dow Futures down 181 points, the S&P Futures down 19 and the NASDAQ Futures lower by 45.

This comes amid an historic oil deal. 23 countries including Saudi Arabia and Russia have agreed to a record production cut of nearly 10 million barrels a day. Oil prices this morning are flat, down as you can see, a fraction at $22.76 a barrel

Mitch Roschelle, are you surprised markets are not happier with this deal? You would expect more of a rally given we are going to see a production cut of almost 10 million.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: I think the big anxiety, Maria, over the market is that earnings start this week. You got the big banks, you got J&J, you got UnitedHealthcare. And I think that that's the big stumbling block right now because we don't have earnings for these companies out and we don't have guidance more importantly. And I think it's what these companies say on conference calls about their forward look on guidance that's going to influence not just the equity markets, but even perhaps the oil markets because we'll know when these businesses going to start ramping up production again.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I'm so glad you brought that up, Mitch, because I'm looking at a note from Peter Boockvar this morning from Bleakley Advisory Group. And he says, forget about the income statement, it's about the balance sheet in the coming weeks. He says the most important thing to watch this earnings season will be the balance sheet, not the income statement. Not only what is your debt to equity ratio or debt to total capital, but what is your interest expense coverage ratio. What debt covenants are you bumping up against? Have you tapped your credit line? And if so, what is left on it?

So all of these things with regard to the debt covenants are going to be much more important than what the company says about how the first quarter look, right, Mitch? Because we're not going back to January, we're not going back to February anytime soon. And we certainly know what happened in March.

ROSCHELLE: Having worked on many restructurings throughout my career, one of the things you start day one is you look at how much cash you have, what's coming in and what your burn rate is on cash. And some of those metrics that are typically only used in troubled companies. Analysts are starting to use on highly profitable companies to figure out how long they can go with the cash that have on hand and their lines of credit.

MCDOWELL: Maria, the --

BARTIROMO: Yes, and Dagen, I don't think even the guidance is going to be very important because they don't know when the economy is going to reopen. And they don't know people's behavior when it does reopen.

MCDOWELL: Right, these companies will give you a big oh when they're talking about what the future looks like. We've already had General Electric, FedEx and Starbucks amongst some of the biggest names warn that they can no longer forecast their own results in such a period of uncertainty.

What the finance chief said at companies far and wide have been doing is tapping the bond markets, extending credit lines, bolstering cash reserves.

The Wall Street Journal writing about this very thing today, but anecdotally, I talk to people in a bunch of different industries like in the fashion industry, in the clothing business, they're just trying to figure out which of the major retailers survive because a lot of them could go away and go away forever. And that would mean the permanent destruction of potentially millions of jobs. That is still the big unknown, despite all these rescues. How many of these jobs go away? And it's really distressing and upsetting to -- you know, not just executives clearly but all of us.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we'll see -- we'll see what they come out with later this week. But certainly, when you look at the earnings per share, it's absolutely irrelevant, because they're going to tell us January and February refine, but we don't know what the future looks like.

So we are going to get those big numbers later on in the week. The first quarter reporting season kicks off this week with JP Morgan and Johnson and Johnson.

Quick break and then how big tech can help keep you safe amid the coronavirus crisis. We'll take a look at that when we come right back. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Apple and Google teaming up to help curb the spread of coronavirus. The technology giant saying that they are building software with contract -- contact tracing. Those contact tracing tools will alert cellphone users if they've come close to anybody with the illness.

Joining us right now is the CyberGuy, Kurt Knutsson. Kurt, this is sure to raise privacy concerns. But it's an interesting take on what technology can do in the face of this pandemic.

KURT KNUTSSON, THE CYBERGUY: Isn't it? Good morning, Maria. You know, it's interesting that Chinese government, which you know, they just mandate whatever they want to mandate on their population. We don't do that here in the U.S. They were very effective with a mandatory app that tracks their population.

Well, what happened was they saw how effective that was. So the powers big tech here in California, Tim Cook along with Sundar Pichai at Google came up and said let's collaborate which is very, very rare for these companies.

And what they came up with is a standard by which in mid-May, we'll start to see what's called an API or the tools for people to develop upon a Bluetooth type of standard that keeps the privacy on your phone where you're not revealing who you are ever. But yet your phone when it comes close to somebody who may be have volunteered that they have COVID-19, it would alert you at some point in changing color saying hi, Maria, you've come close to, ambit expose to and therefore we think you should fill in the blank in terms of protocols health wise at that time to follow, pretty remarkable.

Remarkable that they got together to do this. And the possibilities that technology could actually be the key that unlocks future spread of this epidemic is pretty incredible.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but you don't -- you won't be able to detect someone who may not have said that they have COVID-19 or somebody who doesn't show any symptoms, right? I mean, there's -- so there's that. I mean, I like the idea that at least --

KNUTSSON: There's a weakness right there, you're right -- you're right.

BARTIROMO: You know who has already disclosed. But are there other apps? What are the best apps and maps to monitor the spread of coronavirus?

KNUTSSON: You know, the big warning right now, we've talked about it all morning on, we've talked about it for weeks now is don't click a link from anybody that shares you, hi, download this app. Don't ever click any of that stuff, you go directly yourself.

And some of the real winners here are the obvious ones, and stick with those, the CDC has an outstanding map that connects up with interactive live data. And then the John Hopkins dashboard, which now is embedded around the web is a remarkable tool to just keep your eyes on.

And then -- you know, ironically, private maps like health map, don't necessarily track COVID-19 but it tracks everything in terms of how are people feeling near you.

BARTIROMO: Right.

KNUTSSON: What other type of flu outbreaks are there going on near you? And that can be some beneficial information. At least see what's happening more immediately around you.

BARTIROMO: All right, we'll watch that. Kurt, thank you. Kurt Knutsson.

We're going to take a break and when we come back, Congressman Steve Scalise is here. House Minority Whip joining us on the historic OPEC allies deal, next our MORNINGS WITH MARIA.
